prompt: Critically evaluate the biopsychosocial model of health and illness, including its advantages over reductionist models and challenges in clinical implementation.

criteria.name: Model Comprehension
criteria.description: Explains biological, psychological, and social dimensions and their interactions.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Integrates components with clear interaction examples and historical context.
Analyzes strengths (holism, personalization) and critiques (operationalization, resource burden).

criteria.name: Clinical Application
criteria.description: Translates theory into assessment and intervention.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Provides structured case formulation and multidisciplinary plans; addresses implementation barriers.
performance_descriptors.good: Offers practical examples with moderate specificity.

criteria.name: Evidence Integration
criteria.description: Uses empirical support and real-world cases.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Integrates studies and clinical cases showing model utility and limits.
performance_descriptors.good: Includes relevant evidence with minor gaps.

key_points: Define the model and provide historical context (Engel).
Contrast with biomedical model; note operational challenges.
Provide case formulation template incorporating B-P-S factors.
Discuss multidisciplinary teamwork and coordination issues.
Consider equity, culture, and social determinants.
llm_questions: Create a biopsychosocial case formulation for chronic pain.
What are common barriers to implementing the biopsychosocial model in clinics?
How do social determinants influence health outcomes?
Compare biomedical vs. biopsychosocial approaches in diabetes care.
Design a multidisciplinary care plan using the model.
